8 MAY.part4: As it is written, There is none righteous, no, not one.
8 MAY.part5:
This verse is quoted from Psalm 14, where the Bible gives us a definition of what it means to be a fool. By the world's definition, a fool is a person who behaves unwisely. When one is said to "make a fool of oneself ", he is deemed as a clown who does things that hurt his own reputation and interest. But a fool in God's eyes is one who denies Him: "The fool hath said in his heart, There is no God. They are corrupt, they have done abominable works, there is none that doeth good" [Psalm 14:1]. We are told God looked down from heaven upon the children of men and saying, "They are all gone aside, they are all together become filthy: there is none that doeth good, no, not one" [Psalm 14:3].

It is not difficult to find 'good people' in this world. In fact, the sad reality is that some non- Christians around us might even be better than some Christians according to man's standards. However, from God's vantage point, none of our good deeds is enough to make us righteous before the all-present and all-seeing God. We are totally depraved in that we are born with sin that affects all our faculties, making us unable to seek and to obey God.

A sinner is led by his senses and the ways of this world. The Bible tells us the conscience of a sinner is seared with a hot iron [1 Timothy 4:2], dead in trespasses and sins [Ephesians 2:1]. If not for God's light in our Lord Jesus Christ that cuts through the callousness of our heart, we would be totally lost. There is no way we can save ourselves.
8 MAY.part7: But God, who is rich in mercy, for his great love wherewith he loved us, even when we were dead in sins, hath quickened us together with Christ, (by grace ye are saved). - Ephesians 2:4-5

9 MAY.part5:
Man is made in the image of God. We have a soul and can thus worship God in Spirit; we have a mind and can praise God in Truth. We are moral beings and can differentiate right from wrong; we are social beings and thus can commune with God and have fellowship with one another. But all these are tainted when sin came into this world. Indeed, it is of God's common grace we can still reason and think, and interact with one another. But without God's gracious regeneration and revelation, we are limited and can only do according to our own wisdom and understanding.

It is therefore absolutely true when Paul says, "There is none that understandeth." Man in his presumptuousness may assume he has great knowledge. But it is one thing to know and another thing to understand. In fact, the more he knows, the less he realizes he knows (Socrates). The truth is, the heart of man, in his constant quest for wisdom, is restless, until it rests in God (Augustine).

And when the answer to true wisdom comes, unregenerate man cannot accept it, because of the hardness of his heart. "For the Jews require a sign, and the Greeks seek after wisdom: But we preach Christ crucified, unto the Jews a stumblingblock, and unto the Greeks foolishness; But unto them which are called, both Jews and Greeks, Christ the power of God, and the wisdom of God. Because the foolishness of God is wiser than men, and the weakness of God is stronger than men." [1 Corinthians 1:22-25]
9 MAY.part7: To open their eyes, and to turn them from darkness to light, and from the power of Satan unto God, that they may receive forgiveness of sins, and inheritance among them which are sanctified by faith that is in Me. - Acts 26:18

10 MAY.part4: There is none that seeketh after God.
10 MAY.part5:
Man's volition is often controlled by his feelings and reasoning. Caught in the abyss of sin, he is unable to free himself from its bondage. He indulges in his own lusts and is inflated by his own ego, driving his stakes deep into this world, only to understand the vanity of life when he eventually faces his own mortality. His power to reason is also made captive by his own desires, and he cannot imagine life without the things he is pursuing in this world. He may be able to deceive himself, even the world, with a false impression of happiness and freedom, but the truth is that tragedy awaits him who is trapped in his own web of false hope.

"There is none that seeketh after God." If not for the grace of God working in the foolish heart of the sinner, man is working himself towards condemnation. But all praise to Him who sees us swimming in the miry pool of sin and lifts us up, cleanses us, so that we can see beyond our pathetic state. From then on, things are not the same anymore. We understand true joy and hope, and yearn to live each day fruitfully with the glory of everlasting life ahead of us. We find motivation to change for the sake of God's kingdom.

Indeed, there will be times of weaknesses when our feelings pull us towards the world; there will also be times when our reasoning is impaired by difficult circumstances we are facing in life. But in times like these, we call upon God and continue seeking after Him, and He will hold us up to live from strength to strength, and from grace to grace.
10 MAY.part7: And ye shall seek Me, and find Me, when ye shall search for Me with all your heart. - Jeremiah 29:13

11 MAY.part3: VERSE 11 other words, the sinner, like a corpse, is unable to
11 MAY.part4: There is none that understandeth, there is none that seeketh after God.
11 MAY.part5:
How bad is man's spiritual condition? It is only the extraordinarily arrogant person who has the temerity to claim he has no sin. Most people would admit that they are not perfect, but they are not all bad. Romans 3:10-18, however, paints a devastating portrait of the sinner. The sinner is hopelessly lost. In theology, this is known as the total depravity of man. Paul says that the sinner is dead in his trespasses and sins [Ephesians 2:1]. In other words, the sinner, like a corpse, is unable to respond.

Paul has said that as far as man's moral nature is concerned, there is none who is righteous. With regard to the mind of the natural man, there is none who understands. This inability to understand is not due to a lack of intelligence. It also does not mean that the natural man cannot have a rational understanding of the Christian faith. And it certainly does not mean that the doctrines of the Christian faith are difficult to understand. Rather, man's inability to understand is due to his moral bankruptcy which in turn affects his ability to receive God's truth. Without concealing his sarcasm, Paul asks, "Where is the wise? Where is the scribe? Where is the disputer of this world?" [1 Corinthians 1:20]. The answer is that they are nowhere to be found, and the reason is - as Paul points out - "the world by wisdom knew not God" [1 Corinthians 1:21]. The sinner turns away from God's truth because it does not fit the scheme of his life.

Here is the warning: in turning away from God's truth, we do not become more enlightened. Like a man who turns away from the light, his pathway will become increasingly darker, so sinners who reject God's truth will become "vain in their imaginations, and their foolish heart (will be) darkened" [Romans 1:21].
11 MAY.part7: Do you know the Lord Jesus or do you just know about Him?

12 MAY.part2: There is none that seeketh after God
12 MAY.part4: There is none that understandeth, there is none that seeketh after God.
12 MAY.part5:
The natural man is morally depraved; he is also intellectually defective. What about his will? How does sin affect one's will? Paul says that "there is none that seeketh after God." Again, this statement appears to fly in the face of logic and common observation of the human race. Does not the fact that most people in the world are engaged in the worship of deities imply that the natural man seeks after a higher being?

This question of man's will in seeking after God dates back to the early days of the church. Pelagius - a fourth-century monk - argued that God could not command believers to do the impossible, and that man could not be held responsible for something for which he had no free will. As far as Pelagius is concerned, man is able to exercise his free will to seek or not seek after God.

The Bible teaches the opposite. The natural man is not only totally depraved, but he is also totally unable to save himself. The fallen man - as Augustine of Hippo puts it - cannot not sin. There is a proclivity of the natural man toward sin and not God. Faced with a choice between sin and God, the will of the sinner is bent toward the former. Our Lord Jesus said that the natural man "loved darkness rather than light" [John 3:19].

If God has not pursued us, we would never have come to God by ourselves. This truth exposes the desperate state of the sinner, but it should not drive us to despair. On the contrary, it reveals the essentialness of God's grace, and that the hope for us is not us, but a God who pursues us and His Son who died to redeem us.
12 MAY.part7: No man can come to me, except the Father which hath sent Me draw him. - John 6:44

13 MAY.part4: They are all gone out of the way, they are together become unprofitable; there is none that doeth good, no, not one.
13 MAY.part5:
Israel had forsaken the Lord, departed from His statues, abandoned His worship. Israel is now "like any other man" [Judges 16:17]. The natural man is filled with his own ways, doing that which is right in his own eyes. He delights not in God's ways, nor will he submit to His authority and commandments. His carnal mind is enmity against God and His commandments are grievous to him. He wants to be the captain of his own life. His mentality is that he can manage his own life and make his own decisions, and to depend on God is to be weak. Some even boast and label themselves as "freethinkers" - free from beliefs, free from bondage to anything, and freedom to do whatever they like according to the dictates of their hearts.

There are those who leave the paths of uprightness, to walk in the ways of darkness [Proverbs 2:13]. What fallen man does not realize is that "there is a way which seemeth right unto a man, but the end thereof are the ways of death" [Proverbs 14:12]. He is shorted-sighted and can neither see afar nor the dangers around. He is proud and conceited, stiff-necked and stubborn, refusing divine instruction to walk in the way of life. His thoughts are not God's thoughts, nor his ways God's way.

God in His mercy sometimes afflicts a man, that by his crisis, he may see his own helplessness and foolishness, and discern Him whom God has lifted up - the Way, the Truth, and the Life, the God-Man Christ Jesus.
13 MAY.part7: Prosperity and riches may lull us into spiritual sleep but affliction and crisis awaken us to our own spiritual poverty and helplessness, and our need for and dependence on God.

14 MAY.part4: They are all gone out of the way, they are together become unprofitable; there is none that doeth good, no, not one.
14 MAY.part5:
The Israelites turned away from the law and the prophets, abandoned and corrupted the worship of God, acting in direct contradiction to the truth which God had expressly revealed to them. Thus, they had become unprofitable which carries the idea of fruit becoming rotten and bad-smelling, or decomposing meat with a foul repulsive stench, not fit for intended consumption, unprofitable for its design and purpose.

Their revolt and apostasy, turning to idolatry had become offensive to God, making themselves useless and unfit for what they were designed for - to serve God, to promote His glory, their own good and the good of others. Disobedience and idolatry were evidently the cause of this rottenness. They were worse than filthy rags before God and He would turn away from them, much less use them to show forth His praise and glory.

The writer of the Epistle to the Hebrews wrote about repentance from dead works, that only the blood of our Lord Jesus Christ can purge our conscience from dead works to serve the living God [Hebrews 6:1; 9:14]. Only saving faith in the Lord Jesus, serving Him with our talents for His glory, can result in living and enduring good works. Every man's works shall be made manifest on the day of judgment, and they will be tested by fire to see their worth. Gold, silver and precious stones will withstand the fire, but hay, wood and stubble will all be burnt up [1 Corinthians 3:12-13].
14 MAY.part7: Till men have faith in Christ, their best services are but glorious sins. - Thomas Brooks

15 MAY.part4: They are all gone out of the way, they are together become unprofitable; there is none that doeth good, no, not one.
15 MAY.part5:
After the fall of man to sin, every imagination of the thoughts of his heart was only evil continually [Genesis 6:5]. That was what God saw in the hearts of sinful man. "The heart is deceitful above all things, and desperately wicked: who can know it?" [Jeremiah 17:9]. Is it not true that out of the heart proceed evil thoughts, murders, adulteries, fornications, thefts, false witness, blasphemies [Matthew 15:19]? This filthiness of flesh and spirit are loathsome in the sight of God. If not for His restraining grace, wickedness in this world will go from strength to strength [Genesis 20:6].

The total depravity of man is explicitly and figuratively described in Isaiah 1:6: "From the sole of the foot even unto the head there is no soundness in it; but wounds, and bruises, and putrifying sores: they have not been closed, neither bound up, neither mollified with ointment." Only in the mirror of God's word can we see our true sinful self.

Note, Manasseh was a bad king of Judah. He practised what the heathen did - child sacrifices, observed times, used enchantments, witchcraft, the occult [2 Chronicles 33:6], yet Scripture says he did worse than the heathen [2 Chronicles 33:9]. Why so? Because he had the written word of God and the prophets to enlighten and warn him. Thus, the light he had was far clearer and his obligations to God far greater. Consequently, his sins though same in nature were unspeakably worse in light of these dreadful aggravations. Christian, be admonished!

Amazingly, wicked as Manasseh was, he found forgiveness when he humbled himself, repented and turned to God. Plentiful grace with the Lord Jesus Christ is always found, grace to cover all our sins.
15 MAY.part7: We have three facets of personality - what others think of me, what I think of myself, and what God sees in me.

16 MAY.part4: Their throat is an open sepulchre; with their tongues they have used deceit; the poison of asps is under their lips.
16 MAY.part5:
Today, we look at what God's Word tells us about an organ that He has given to man for his use: the mouth (including the throat, tongue and all other parts therein). Firstly, we see that God in His wisdom gave us a mouth for multiple uses: to eat (and drink), speak, and even to breathe (we breathe through our mouth as well as nose). God has given us an efficient body which does not require separate organs for each of the functions mentioned above. We can extend this idea to the rest of our body, and indeed, God created man to be able to do multiple things with the same body.

Let us focus on the words that come out of our mouths. Even words have multiple uses, and one thing is sure, words can be meant for good or for evil. Consider the words "build" and "destroy". A cursory look may make us think the former is good, and the latter bad, but consider Genesis 6:7 where God told Noah that He will destroy all that He had created.

God is holy and good in all He does and thus He meant it for good even in destroying His creation. The lesson, therefore, is twofold: firstly, we must be careful not to be hasty in reading into a word that is said to us. Secondly, we also need to be careful with our words, and ask ourselves: "What is the intent in our hearts when we say those words?" Do we intend them for good or do we mean it for evil?
16 MAY.part7: The heart of the righteous studieth to answer: but the mouth of the wicked poureth out evil things. - Proverbs 15:28

17 MAY.part4: Their throat is an open sepulchre; with their tongues they have used deceit; the poison of asps is under their lips.
17 MAY.part5:
Have you ever been told something that turns out to be untrue? Or have you said something that is untrue to deceive someone? Lying has been a common sin amongst us ever since the serpent lied to Adam and Eve in the Garden of Eden. The devil lied to Eve to deceive her into eating the forbidden fruit by painting a false picture of the benefits of eating the fruit. At the same time, he also lied about God's intentions, planting seeds of distrust in Adam and Eve. Such is the nature of lies, deceiving the hearer into believing the speaker, and changing the way one thinks about someone or something.

In this day and age, when information is easily disseminated through the digital media, it is all the more important to be aware of what is true and what is not. Fake news is abundant on the Internet and unsuspecting readers can be easily deceived into thinking what they are reading is true. Fake news even come knocking at our doors via chatgroups and mobile apps, so readers beware and do not be part of the web of lies by forwarding unconfirmed news when you receive them.

While deceit is becoming more widespread today, we can take comfort in the knowledge that God is in control and He is the source of all truth. Let us be wise, pray for discernment, and may God guide us and prompt us when confronted with deceiving words.
17 MAY.part7: Wherefore putting away lying, speak every man truth with his neighbour. - Ephesians 4:25a

18 MAY.part4: Whose mouth is full of cursing and bitterness
18 MAY.part5:
When God created the first garden and gave Adam and Eve all the fruits of the garden for food, God also gave them sweet-tasting food, not bitter ones. Similarly today, we enjoy good- tasting food, but when something tastes bad in our mouths, we know and immediately spit it out. The same applies to our other senses - whether something feels, looks and sounds good or bad, we can discern and accept or reject them accordingly. In the same manner, words can also be sweet or bitter to the hearer. In fact, we speak and listen to words more than we eat and drink daily.

Therefore, words are a powerful means of communicating not just knowledge but also emotions and feelings of the speaker. Imagine two people quarrelling. What kind of words are normally exchanged? Certainly destructive and angry words, full of cursing and bitterness. Words that hurt not just the ears but pierce through the hearts of its hearers. A father who tells his child he is useless and will never do well in life may be even more hurtful to the child than physical punishment. Worse, the child learns to do the same to others, using hurtful and bitter words as he grows up.

Thus let us use our words wisely, being careful not to cause unnecessary hurt to others. Avoid bitter and hurtful words. Rather, use words that build each other up, to encourage one another. In so doing, we show forth God's love so that others may see the Lord Jesus Christ in us.
18 MAY.part7: Let us therefore follow after the things which make for peace, and things wherewith one may edify another. - Romans 14:19

19 MAY.part4: Their feet are swift to shed blood.
19 MAY.part5:
From verses 15 to 17, we read further regarding the ways of the wicked - the character and behaviour of godless people who are without the Lord Jesus Christ in their lives. This is a metaphorical picture of a person's character. Paul is quoting from Isaiah 59:7-8 to illustrate man's sinful nature.

Looking back at verse 13, the sin of the tongue is included to conclude the list of sins committed against God. We use our tongue too freely to backbite our fellow beings. The Bible warns us of misusing our tongue in James 3:8. In the same breath from the same person, that tongue is used to sing praises to God in church.

It is the same with the other body parts, as mentioned in verse 15 here. Our feet will go where the heart leads, which is so willing to do evil. Human beings are so ready to backbite and criticize one another. This only shows the person is not a believer, especially when he persists in his wrongdoing.

We should not be surprised at the unbeliever's persistence because he is under Satan's control. He is spiritually blinded and lured away by the lust of the flesh, the lust of the eyes and the pride of life [1 John 2:15-17]. Hence, he will continue in his wrong doings. Man's evil deeds may not be seen by his friends but nothing and no one can hide his actions from God. We may even escape their consequences now, but the day of final reckoning will catch up with us. Be warned that judgment is sure and certain.
19 MAY.part7: We are accountable to God for our deeds.

20 MAY.part4: And the way of peace have they not known:
20 MAY.part5:
To be expected, destruction and misery will follow the sinful way. Nothing good will result from any deed done with evil intentions. If one does not seek God's will, they will not have peace. Sadly, the unregenerate man does not seek to do God's will but just the opposite. And nothing good can come out of their evil deeds.

Every one of us is accountable for our own actions, no matter how harmless or unintentional they are. Hebrews 9:27 says, "And as it is appointed unto men once to die, but after this the judgment."

Have you ever been troubled by a guilty conscience over something you said in jest but was taken seriously by your friend? Surely, the misery you felt was terrible. No one and nothing could make you feel better. In fact, sometimes you even feel worse when that friend is so forgiving.

The evil deeds committed in verse 15 are much more serious, yet we are all equally guilty before God. Judgement is sure and certain for both Jews and Gentiles. It is pointless to say that the liar is better than the murderer because both are guilty of wrongdoing. It is useless to compare ourselves with others for all will face the same judgement one day. We need to confess our sin and ask the Lord to cleanse us and receive Him as our personal Lord and Saviour.
20 MAY.part7: As it is written, There is none righteous, no, not one. - Romans 3:10

21 MAY.part4: There is no fear of God before their eyes.
21 MAY.part5: The godless have no peace simply because they do not have any fear for God. In this verse the word "fear" means "respect", "reverence". It does not mean "terror" or "be frightened of " as used today. Note that the three short verses preceding verse 18, when read in reverse, are interrelated and refer to the outcome of the lack of reverence for God. There are many references to God-fearing characters in the Bible. David for one sought to do God's will in obedience to His Word. The importance of Psalm 19:7-11 is a good reminder for us to respect God and His Word, thus staying close to Him. The fear and respect of God and His Word will result in knowing the peace of God. We are assured of this peace in Philippians 4:7: "And the peace of God, which passeth all understanding, shall keep your hearts and minds through Christ Jesus". What God promises here is true, inner peace of soul and spirit. Every child of God is a sinner saved by grace through faith in the Lord Jesus Christ. We are imperfect, but we are clothed in the righteousness of Christ. Let us live in thankful obedience and share the joy of our salvation with those who do not know Him. Do you have the peace of God in your heart? If not, delay no longer. Right this moment, pray the prayer of salvation to accept Jesus Christ as your personal Lord and Saviour. Then you will definitely experience the joy of inner peace in Him.
21 MAY.part7: Peace, peace, sweet peace! Wonderful gift from above! O, wonderful, wonderful peace! Sweet peace, the gift of God's love! - Peter P. Bilhorn

22 MAY.part3: VERSE 19 and reflect on our lives, we will have to admit we
22 MAY.part4: Now we know that what things soever the law saith, it saith to them who are under the law: that every mouth may be stopped, and all the world may become guilty before God.
22 MAY.part5:
No one will be declared righteous in God's sight by His laws. God gives each of us a conscience to know that we are not able to fulfil the law of God. Our ego leads us to unbelief and to justify our goodness, that we are not that bad. Man chooses to be answerable to himself. We suppress the knowledge God has given us, that is, the knowledge we have broken His laws. If we are honest in measuring ourselves against God's law and reflect on our lives, we will have to admit we come up far short. We are guilty before God.

The penalty of sin is eternal death. Our effort and whatever good we try to do will not admit us to heaven because we are unable to achieve the standard set by God. In other words, we are guilty as charged. But our Lord Jesus came to redeem us. Instead of us dying for our own sins, our Lord took our punishment and died on the behalf of those who believe in Him. He gives us an opportunity to receive Him as our Saviour. When we face God after death, we can boldly say that the Lord Jesus paid for our sins. God grants all who have Jesus in their hearts a place in Heaven to dwell with Him forever. Why does God need to do this for man? He knows we will come short of His laws. It is solely out of love that our Lord Jesus came. It is out of His mercy and grace that we have the opportunity to listen to the Gospel and understand it. And we are to tell this good news that saves to others so that they too are able to dwell in Heaven forever.
22 MAY.part7: Therefore by the deeds of the law there shall no flesh be justified in his sight: for by the law is the knowledge of sin. - Romans 3:20

23 MAY.part4: Now we know that what things soever the law saith, it saith to them who are under the law: that every mouth may be stopped, and all the world may become guilty before God.
23 MAY.part5:
What would your answer be when you die and face God? The question He will ask is "What right do you have to be allowed into Heaven?" You can justify that you have always been a good person and did not hurt anyone. You did not break the law of the land. Whatever good you have done is of no value unless you are perfect in keeping God's law to the minutest detail. You have sinned daily. No one is able to keep all of God's laws. In reality, there is nothing you can say because deep down in your heart you know you have sinned. The scripture records for us that Job kept silent when God asked him to justify himself [Job 38-41]. Isaiah dared not speak until the Lord cleansed his mouth with a piece of burning coal [Isaiah 6:6]. Habakkuk could not talk but trembled at what God revealed to him [Habakkuk 3:16]. John fell at the Lord Jesus Christ's feet "as though dead" and was in dead silence [Revelation 1:17]. Why did these great men of God keep silent? They knew that it was best to keep silent because God is the Almighty who demands we be sinless. Like everyone else; we are unable to keep all of God's law. We can only remain silent before the Almighty God.

But God sent the Lord Jesus to bear our sins. Jesus is the only sinless One who is also God. Therefore, all who accept Him as their Saviour will be justified and be counted sinless as their sins are forgiven and borne by Him. God will allow us into His Heaven only on the merit of our Lord Jesus Christ our redeemer.
23 MAY.part7: Knowing that a man is not justified by the works of the law, but by the faith of Jesus Christ, even we have believed in Jesus Christ, that we might be justified by the faith of Christ, and not by the works of the law: for by the works of the law shall no flesh be justified. - Galatians 2:16

24 MAY.part2: Why Deeds of the Law  Cannot Justify (I)
24 MAY.part4: Therefore by the deeds of the law there shall no flesh be justified in his sight: for by the law is the knowledge of sin.
24 MAY.part5:
Paul has exposed the unrighteousness of both Jews and Gentiles. All are guilty and condemned before God. There are no exceptions. "Therefore," Paul concludes here, "by the deeds of the law there shall no flesh be justified in his sight."

The "deeds of the law" refer to works of righteousness, done in obedience to God's law. Paul states unequivocally that no one will be justified (declared righteous in God's sight) by observing the law. There is nothing we can do to atone for our sins and be set free from the guilty sentence and condemnation. Put simply, no one will be saved by good works.

But good works are a necessary part of the Christian faith. Our Lord Jesus commands us to keep His commandments as evidence of our love for Him [John 14:15]. Good works, however, are not the basis of our salvation, but the result of it. We are saved for good works, not by good works. We can do nothing to merit our salvation. The deeds of the law cannot justify anyone.

Maybe you think that you have done many good works, being kind and helpful to others, generous to the poor, even serving fervently in church ministries. None of these will make you good enough for heaven. All we can do is come before God with a humble and contrite heart, and seek His grace, remembering we are saved not by our works, but by God's grace through faith in our Lord Jesus Christ.
24 MAY.part7: Nothing in my hands I bring, simply to Thy cross I cling; naked, come to Thee for dress, helpless, look to Thee for grace: - Augustus M. Toplady

25 MAY.part2: Why Deeds of the Law Cannot Justify (Il)
25 MAY.part4: Therefore by the deeds of the law there shall no flesh be justified in his sight: for by the law is the knowledge of sin.
25 MAY.part5:
Why can't the deeds of the law justify? The problem does not lie with the law. Psalm 19:7 tells us that "the law of the LORD is perfect, converting the soul". Paul states in Romans 2:13 that "doers of the law shall be justified". All those who obey the law perfectly will be accepted as righteous before God.

Yet, in reality, no one will be justified by keeping the law because of mankind's fallen nature. Instead of pursuing God and trying to please Him, the entire human race actually tries to get away from God. Far from observing the law, human beings actually violate the law in all possible ways and are thoroughly wicked. This does not mean every human being is as wicked as he can possibly be. Rather, sin has corrupted every part of our being - our body, our mind, and our will. We are enslaved to the evil impulses and desires of the heart.

As Paul has demonstrated, no man has fulfilled the strict requirements of the law. Our best efforts are laced with sin, and our most "righteous" deeds fall far short of God's glory. Even if we observe the law outwardly, the attitudes and actions of our hearts often condemn us. There is none righteous [Romans 3:10]. All have sinned and stand guilty before God.

Righteousness cannot come from the "deeds of the law" or any form of self-effort. We need the righteousness, which is found only in Christ Jesus, which can only be obtained by grace through faith in Him.
25 MAY.part7: But that no man is justified by the law in the sight of God, it is evident: for, The just shall live by faith. - Galatians 3:11

26 MAY.part4: Therefore by the deeds of the law there shall no flesh be justified in his sight: for by the law is the knowledge of sin.
26 MAY.part5:
The first part of verse 20 tells us what the law is unable to do - it is unable to justify sinful man. Nobody will be declared righteous by observing the law. God did not give the law as a means to salvation. It is not a checklist for us to earn our way to heaven.

In the second half of verse 20, Paul shows us what the law can do - it gives men the knowledge of sin. Apart from the law, we will not realise how sinful we are. We may think that we are basically good moral people, especially when we compare ourselves against crooks and criminals. But it is against God's standard that we should measure ourselves. Unless we attain God's standard of righteousness, no one is righteous enough to enter heaven.

God reveals His standard to us through His law. It is only when we measure ourselves against God's law that we begin to see how far short we are of God's righteous demands. We are all wretched sinners condemned to His wrath and just punishment. There is no way we can save ourselves. We need a Saviour.

So, this is the purpose of the law - not a means of our justification but a measure of our unworthiness. Do you see yourself as a guilty condemned sinner awaiting God's judgment? Let the law lead you to His throne of grace, where you can obtain mercy and forgiveness of sins through faith in the Lord Jesus Christ.
26 MAY.part7: No man can justify himself before God by a perfect performance of the Law's demands - indeed it is the straight-edge of the Law that shows us how crooked we are. - J. B. Phillips

27 MAY.part3: VERSE 21 introduced the words "but now" in verse 21.
27 MAY.part4: But now the righteousness of God without the law is manifested, being witnessed by the law and the prophets.
27 MAY.part5:
Paul established the unrighteousness of all mankind in the first three chapters of Romans. All have fallen short of God's righteous demands and stand guilty before Him. No one can be declared righteous by observing the law. The law convicts and condemns the whole human race but is unable to save anyone.

Just when everything seems hopeless, as mankind awaits God's judgment and wrath, Paul introduced the words "but now" in verse 21. This marks the turning point in God's dealings with man. However bleak things have been in the earlier chapters, changes take place from this point onwards.

What are these changes? We were under God's wrath and unable to save ourselves through our own work-righteousness, but now God reveals to us His righteousness which is apart from the law. All were under condemnation, but now, all who believe in the Lord Jesus Christ are justified freely by God's grace. Before, we were under the bondage of sin and unable to keep the law, but now in Christ, we are set free from sin and enabled to live holy lives. Before, Gentiles were excluded from God's covenant, but now, all who put their faith in the Lord Jesus are brought into God's covenant family.

What wonderful news of God's grace Paul introduced with the words "but now"! Are you still walking down the path of sin and destruction, without hope and without God in this life? "But now" there is hope through faith in Christ Jesus. Now is the time to turn from sin and turn to the Lord Jesus Christ!
27 MAY.part7: I once was lost, but now am found; was blind, but now I see. - John Newton

28 MAY.part2: The Righteousness of God Without the Law
28 MAY.part4: But now the righteousness of God without the law is manifested, being witnessed by the law and the prophets;
28 MAY.part5:
When a man comes before God for judgment, he will be pronounced righteous and accepted by God, in other words, justified, if he has fulfilled all the requirements of the law. However, as Paul demonstrated, no man is able to fulfil the law perfectly. Therefore no one can be righteous before God by his works.

If man possesses no righteousness of his own, how can he ever be deemed righteous before God? The good news is God provides righteousness. Paul calls this the "righteousness of God without the law". This righteousness is God's righteousness: how He acts in accordance with His holy nature to put people in a right relationship with Himself. God's righteousness is revealed in the person and work of the Lord Jesus. By His sinless life of perfect obedience and by bearing the full penalty for our sins on the cross, the Lord Jesus Christ made it possible for sinners to be forgiven and declared righteous by God.

The phrase "righteousness of God" also means this righteousness comes from God. It is not obtained by keeping the law but given freely to men by grace through faith in the Lord Jesus. We do not deserve it and can do nothing to earn it. It is a gift of God.

Do you rely on the things you are doing for yourself or even for God, for your salvation? Or do you trust in the Lord Jesus and what He has done? Cease from your work and rest in the finished work of Christ. True righteousness comes, not by the law, but through faith in Christ.
28 MAY.part7: Yea doubtless, and I count all things but loss for the excellency of the knowledge of Christ Jesus my Lord: for whom I have suffered the loss of all things, and do count them but dung, that I may win Christ, and be found in him, not having mine own righteousness, which is of the law, but that which is through the faith of Christ, the righteousness which is of God by faith. - Philippians 3:8-9

29 MAY.part4: But now the righteousness of God without the law is manifested, being witnessed by the law and the prophets.
29 MAY.part5:
Paul has just revealed the good news of how God's righteousness is available to all who put their faith in Christ. This gospel is new in the sense that the coming of the Lord Jesus Christ inaugurates a new stage in salvation history. Yet, Paul also reminds us that it is not entirely new. As attested to by the Law and the Prophets, that is the Old Testament, the means of salvation that God has provided for His people has remained unchanged throughout history - by grace through faith in Christ. Those born before the Lord Jesus were saved by looking forward in faith to the coming of Christ, while those born after were saved by looking back in faith to His finished work.

How does the Old Testament testify to God's grace through the Lord Jesus Christ? From the very beginning, after Adam and Eve fell into sin, God spoke of the coming of a mighty One who would destroy Satan and his works forever [Genesis 3:15]. The sacrificial system of the Mosaic Law points to the perfect sacrifice that God will ultimately provide, His own Son, the Lord Jesus Christ - the paschal lamb of God who takes away the sin of the world. The prophets gave numerous prophecies of Christ, especially His birth and His suffering and death for sinners.

What is your attitude towards the Old Testament? Is it a history book about the bygone era of salvation by the Law, or is it a testament of God's faithfulness to His covenant as He unfolds His plan of redeeming grace culminating in the work of the Lord Jesus Christ?
29 MAY.part7: The Bible is the one Word of the one God about the one way of salvation through the one Savior, Jesus Christ. - Graeme Goldsworthy

30 MAY.part2: The Righteousness of God by Faith
30 MAY.part4: Even the righteousness of God which is by faith of Jesus Christ unto all and upon all them that believe: for there is no difference.
30 MAY.part5:
Paul writes to the Romans to stress that no one can hope to behave perfectly to achieve God's required standard of righteousness. Only those who have faith in the Lord Jesus Christ have the righteousness of God.

Paul's message reveals to us the glorious hope of our salvation: the righteousness God requires is not something we can hope to attain through our own efforts. It is not righteousness earned through obedience to the law. It is righteousness received through faith in Jesus Christ. It is transformative and something which happens to us. Paul describes the righteousness of God as something "revealed" [Romans 1:17] and "manifested" (shown or demonstrated) [v. 21].

A murderer stands before the judge to receive his sentence. He has no hope of redeeming himself. The verdict is obvious - this murderer's sentence is death. Facing imminent death, the murderer confesses his guilt and begs for mercy. Inexplicably, another man, a perfectly law-abiding innocent man, in the courtroom stands up to take the place of the condemned. He dies in the murderer's place. The judge deems the murderer's punishment served in the eyes of the law and he walks free.

In the same way, the Lord Jesus Christ who was perfect in all ways and "who knew no sin" [2 Corinthians 5:21] stood up, took our place to bear the punishment for our sins. Through Christ, we have the glorious hope of salvation - the righteousness of God through faith in our Lord.
30 MAY.part7: Amazing love! how can it be That Thou, my God, shouldst die for me? - Charles Wesley

31 MAY.part4: Even the righteousness of God which is by faith of Jesus Christ unto all and upon all them that believe: for there is no difference.
31 MAY.part5:
There is no difference with regard to man's need of the Gospel. Superficially, it might seem some among us are morally purer and more upright. Yet the Bible tells us plainly that "there is none righteous, no, not one" [v. 10]. The Bible does not say some people are less sinful than others. There is no difference - all have sinned and come short of the glory of God.

There is also no difference with regard to God's salvation plan for man. It does not matter how intelligent or privileged people are, the message of salvation remains the same - we are only righteous before God through faith in the Lord Jesus Christ. No special privileges are extended to those who are wealthier, smarter or born into a Christian family. There is only one way to heaven for our Lord Jesus says, "I am the Way, the Truth, and the Life: no man cometh unto the Father, but by Me" [John 14:6]. Nothing can take away the stain of guilt except the blood of Jesus Christ.

Some think, "I have done all I can to be obedient in God's sight". Others are troubled by their fears and think, "I am such a great sinner! I am so evil, uncaring and cannot love the Lord and His people as I want to." There is no difference. Both groups equally need the righteousness of God, which is freely and equally available to those who believe in our Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ.
31 MAY.part7: Lord, thank You that You are the righteous God who has chosen to redeem mankind by the death and resurrection of Your Son. Thank You that I am justified by the righteousness of God through faith in the Lord Jesus, the perfect and only sacrifice for the sin of the world. In Jesus' name, Amen.

1 JUNE.part4: For all have sinned, and come short of the glory of God.
1 JUNE.part5:
Jews may have the law and circumcision; Americans may lay claim to a great religious heritage; "good" people may point to their works of charity; but all this makes no essential difference to one's standing before the righteous and holy God. No wonder there is no difference, when both the one and the other have the guilt of Adam's transgression imputed to them, and have original corruption inherent in them, from whence proceed very many actual transgressions.

If you are asked to try and jump to the moon, some would do no more than a foot from the ground. The world's champion high jumper will be able to jump about eight feet off the ground. With the use of a pole, the champion pole vaulter could swing himself twenty-odd feet above the ground. But that is all. No one can reach the moon by their own unaided efforts. And the man who jumps twenty feet high is not much nearer the moon than the elderly lady who manages but six inches. Likewise, we may think that we are more righteous than others, but compared to the ultimate standard of God, we fall short, abysmally short, miserably short. All have sinned and are falling short of God's glory.

Knowing we all have missed the standard teaches us that all share the same need for the righteousness only God can give. Thankfully, it is available to all who believe, without distinction being made between the Jew and Gentile.
1 JUNE.part7: We are all on equal standing at the foot of the cross. All have sinned and all need the Lord Jesus Christ.

2 JUNE.part3: VERSE 24 Here Paul uses the word "freely" to modify
2 JUNE.part4: Being justified freely by his grace through the redemption that is in Christ Jesus:
2 JUNE.part5:
As Paul uses it in this verse, the verb "justify" does not mean to "make righteous" (in an ethical sense) nor simply to "treat as righteous" (when one is really not righteous), but to "declare righteous". Sinners stand condemned in God's court, and yet God declares believers not guilty because of the work our Lord Jesus has finished on the cross. What a joy! A sinner destined for eternal punishment being acquitted of all charges!

Here Paul uses the word "freely" to modify justify. Justification is something God bestows as a gift. That which is a gift is not earned nor deserved. Your status in society, wealth, intellect, church attendance could never merit this gift. Whatever you do (or do not) can never earn this free gift. This is further emphasized when Paul adds we are justified freely by His grace. This is the real heart of the issue: merit or grace? And God's justifying verdict is totally unmerited. People have done nothing and can do nothing to earn it. God is unconstrained by anything other than His own will. This truly is the undeserved love and mercy of God.

Paul has already established that all have sinned and fall short of the glory of God [v. 23] and have set the Jews and Gentiles on equal footing. All have missed the mark. Likewise, all those which "believeth in Jesus" [v. 26], Jew or Gentile, will be declared righteous before God.
2 JUNE.part7: The love of God is greater far Than tongue or pen can ever tell It goes beyond the highest star And reaches to the lowest hell. - Frederick Martin Lehman

3 JUNE.part4: Being justified freely by his grace through the redemption that is in Christ Jesus:
3 JUNE.part5:
Torrential rain falls upon the houses of believers and unbelievers alike; scorching rays similarly dry up the gardens of Christians and non- Christians. Likewise, the grace of God falls "on the just and on the unjust" [Matthew 5:45]. This is called the common grace of God.

Think about the grand scale of the universe. Since God is not dependent on anything outside Himself, He did not create the universe out of necessity. That the universe continues on at all is the result of God's free will and grace to sustain it. Universal and indiscriminate towards unbelievers is God's common grace as we exist in this world. God did not set all the laws of the universe in motion like a spinning top and then let it be. It is unimaginable what the repercussions would be even if God were to take a short break from sustaining the universe. Truly "by him all things consist" [Colossians 1:17].

In addition to the common grace of God is the saving or special grace of God. All those that put their faith and trust in the Lord are recipients of this saving grace. Although our sinful nature resists God, God gives the Holy Spirit to the elect making them willing and able to believe. Saving grace operates in producing conviction of sin and repentance. The gift of faith in our Lord Jesus Christ is bestowed upon believers and justifies us of all sin. Completely unmerited and free is this saving grace of God.
3 JUNE.part7: For by grace are ye saved through faith; and that not of yourselves: it is the gift of God. - Ephesians 2:8

4 JUNE.part3: VERSE 24 it required the death of His Son as the atoning
4 JUNE.part4: Being justified freely by his grace through the redemption that is in Christ Jesus:
4 JUNE.part5:
What if God had simply swept our sin under the rug and ignored it? He would be unjust for leaving sin unjudged and not addressing its penalty. His justice demands payment for sins committed; anything short of that would have impugned His character. Our lives are the obvious payment for sin [Romans 6:23]. But God chose a different path, one in which He remained just, but also justified us. This option was very costly since it required the death of His Son as the atoning sacrifice. As a result, we are redeemed by the blood of our Lord Jesus.

The Greek word for "redemption" in verse 24 is a compound word (apo-lutosis), the latter of which means ransom. In the Septuagint (the Greek translation of the Old Testament), the word is used to denote the price for one's life [Exodus 21:30]. In Isaiah 45:13, it is implied that there is a ransom to be paid to liberate a slave or captive. It is along these lines Paul is using this word presenting our Lord Jesus' death as a ransom or payment that takes the place of that penalty for sins owed by all people to God. God, in our Lord Jesus, pays the price necessary to redeem His people from their slavery to sin.

To whom was the ransom paid? It would be incorrect to presume that our Lord Jesus paid a ransom to the devil, in order to buy us back from Satan's possession. The ransom or purchase price is not paid to Satan. It is paid to God, for it is to God that we are in debt.
4 JUNE.part7: For even the Son of man came not to be ministered unto, but to minister, and to give his life a ransom for many. - Mark 10:45

5 JUNE.part4: Being justified freely by his grace through the redemption that is in Christ Jesus:
5 JUNE.part5:
Redemption comes at a price. The price was the life of our Lord Jesus Christ. It is in our Lord Jesus that "we have redemption through his blood" [Ephesians 1:7]. This price is illustrated in the Old Testament story of Ruth and Boaz. The tragic death of Ruth's husband, father-in-law and brother-in-law left Ruth and her mother-in-law, Naomi, without a provider and protector. To ensure that widows like Ruth were not taken advantage of, God instituted the law of the kinsman-redeemer in Deuteronomy 25:5-6. In such circumstances, the nearest male relative would take Ruth and bear a son to succeed and carry on the name of the deceased husband.

Boaz, in stepping up to be the kinsman- redeemer for Ruth, is obliged to provide for Ruth and her future family. His wealth is diluted in order to carry on the name of another man. This is the price that Boaz paid in exchange for adding the surviving spouse of the deceased husband to his overall estate.

Justification comes at a cost too. Sin must be punished. To save lost sinners, God sent the Lord Jesus to take on our sins as if He committed them Himself. That God sent his "only begotten Son" [John 3:16] whom He has been in a loving relationship with from eternity past, to die on the cross for undeserving sinners like you and me is the greatest story of mercy and redemption. Oh, how deep is His love!
5 JUNE.part7: Dear God, thank You for redeeming me out of darkness into Your marvellous light. Help me to witness to others of this salvation so rich and so free. In Jesus' name, Amen.

6 JUNE.part4: Whom God hath set forth to be a propitiation through faith in his blood, to declare his righteousness for the remission of sins that are past, through the forbearance of God.
6 JUNE.part5:
God the Father has set forth His only begotten Son, the Lord Jesus to be a propitiation. "Propitiation" carries the idea of a sacrifice that appeases God's holy wrath. God being holy and righteous has to judge sin. He cannot overlook it.

"For thus saith the LORD of hosts; As I thought to punish you, when your fathers provoked me to wrath, saith the LORD of hosts, and I repented not" [Zechariah 8:14].

It is God Himself who has put forward a means to satisfy His own righteous anger and judgment - a propitiation, an appeasing sacrifice. It is all God's work and nothing that mankind has done. God placates Himself as only He can.

This same Greek word "propitiation" is translated "mercy seat" in Hebrews 9:5. The Old Testament records in Exodus 25 and 37 how God instructed the Israelites in the construction of the tabernacle to house the ark of the covenant. The mercy seat sat as a lid over the ark and was where God dwelt between the cherubs and would meet His people [Exodus 25:22]. The High Priest would enter the Holy of Holies on the Day of Atonement and sprinkle the blood of a bullock and goat onto and around the mercy seat [Leviticus 16] as God instructed, to atone for the nation's sins.

Thus, propitiation also conveys the idea of a place where atonement is obtained. Being "atoned for" means to obtain mercy, to be wiped clean, have sin purged and be covered over, thus achieving reconciliation in order that sinners can come before an assuaged God.
6 JUNE.part7: For He, being full of compassion, forgave their iniquity, and destroyed them not: yea, many a time turned He His anger away, and did not stir up all His wrath. - Psalm 78:38

7 JUNE.part4: Whom God hath set forth to be a propitiation through faith in his blood, to declare his righteousness for the remission of sins that are past, through the forbearance of God.
7 JUNE.part5:
Propitiation does not come free. There is a price to be paid to appease God. A holy righteous God who has been offended demands justice or He would not be just. The system for propitiation / atonement had been laid out by God in the Old Testament. Moses was commanded by God to instruct the High Priest: "Then shall he kill the goat of the sin offering, that is for the people, and bring his blood within the vail, and do with that blood as he did with the blood of the bullock, and sprinkle it upon the mercy seat, and before the mercy seat." [Leviticus 16:15]

God demands that blood be shed as the price of propitiation. The animal sacrifices by themselves were not able to atone for the people's sins. "For it is not possible that the blood of bulls and of goats should take away sins" [Hebrews 10:4]. The system of sacrifices in the Old Testament with blood of animals shed, were a foreshadowing [Hebrews 10:1] of God's foreordained ultimate means of atonement for His people: "But this man, after he had offered one sacrifice for sins for ever, sat down on the right hand of God" [Hebrews 10:12].

The Lord Jesus is the Lamb of God who takes away the sin of the world [John 1:29] by the shedding of His precious blood on the Cross of Calvary [Ephesians 1:7].
7 JUNE.part7: Forasmuch as ye know that ye were not redeemed with corruptible things ... but with the precious blood of Christ, as of a lamb without blemish and without spot. - 1 Peter 1:18-19

8 JUNE.part4: Whom God hath set forth to be a propitiation through faith in his blood, to declare his righteousness for the remission of sins that are past, through the forbearance of God.
8 JUNE.part5:
It is out of God's forbearance that the Lord Jesus is given as an appeasing sacrifice, so sinners may be reconciled. God is a forbearing God as that is His character. To forbear is to be patient, to tolerate and endure. With regards to sinful creatures who deserve righteous judgment, forbearance results in punishment being deferred for a time. In effect, God is restraining Himself from punishing the sinner at the very same moment that sin is committed. It does not mean God ignores it altogether. He is showing His willingness to delay His punishment for a time. The fact that He would purpose His own Son as a wrath-appeasing sacrifice shows that He still hates and judges sin. Because of God's forbearance, righteousness and being gracious to save, the Lord Jesus is sent to save us from His wrath.

God tolerates mankind's sin for a time, suspending punishment for a while, in order that sinners have the opportunity to be spared by exercising faith in His Son's atoning work in shedding His precious blood on Calvary's Cross. He will then remit even their past sins because they are covered by the shed blood of His foreordained sacrifice. Such forbearance must never be mocked nor spurned.

"And the times of this ignorance God winked at; but now commandeth all men every where to repent: Because he hath appointed a day, in the which he will judge the world in righteousness by that man whom he hath ordained; whereof he hath given assurance unto all men, in that he hath raised him from the dead." [Acts 17:30-31]
8 JUNE.part7: Herein is love, not that we loved God, but that He loved us, and sent His Son to be the propitiation for our sins. - 1 John 4:10

9 JUNE.part2: Three Words -- Justification, Redemption and Propitiation
9 JUNE.part4: Whom God hath set forth to be a propitiation through faith in his blood, to declare his righteousness for the remission of sins that are past, through the forbearance of God.
9 JUNE.part5:
The instruction of the Christian faith has been greatly hindered by the death of great words. In Romans 3:24-25, we have three great words - justification, redemption and propitiation. And all three words have to do with soteriology (the doctrine of salvation). Paul's writings in Romans gives the clearest and most thorough presentation of these words.

Justification is the act of being pronounced righteous. God assumes the position of the righteous Judge by which He does not impute to the sinner the penalty for his sin, but by grace imputes to him righteousness by faith in Christ Jesus. The idea that righteousness can be imputed by faith in a Person and not through the Law goes against the human understanding of fairness.

Redemption means deliverance by the blood of our Lord Jesus Christ [Ephesians 1:7; Colossians 1:14]. There are two aspects of redemption; redemption from sin [Ephesians 1:7] and redemption unto glory [Ephesians 1:14]. The picture is that sin has and will hold us captive, but for our Lord Jesus Christ. Sin, therefore, has no dominion over redeemed sinners. However, the full and final release from sin will not be realised until we see our Saviour face to face.

The word propitiation is also translated as "mercy seat" [Hebrews 9:5]. It is closely linked to sacrifice. We ought not to think of propitiation as the turning aside of God's wrath by anything that we do. Rather it is as Paul puts it - "propitiation through faith in His blood." It is God Himself - being perfectly righteous and just - satisfying His wrath against sinners by demanding the sacrificial death of His only begotten Son.
9 JUNE.part7: Do you realise that Christ is your Ransomer and has actually shed His blood for you as your ransom? ... Do you realise that this Christ who has thus shed His blood for you is Himself your God. - B. B. Warfield

10 JUNE.part4: Whom God hath set forth to be a propitiation through faith in his blood, to declare his righteousness for the remission of sins that are past, through the forbearance of God.
10 JUNE.part5:
What is faith? The writer of Hebrews defines faith - "Now faith is the substance of things hoped for, the evidence of things not seen" [Hebrews 11:1]. In the Institutes of the Christian Religion, John Calvin defines faith as the "firm and certain knowledge of God's benevolence toward us, founded upon the truth of the freely given promise in Christ, both revealed to our minds and sealed upon our hearts by the Holy Spirit."

By Calvin's definition, faith comprises three elements: notitia, assensus, and fiducia. Notitia is the content of faith. True faith must be based on "knowledge of the truth". In order to believe, we must know something about that Someone, who is our Lord Jesus Christ. He is the object of our faith. Our faith must be in Christ. Without the right content, there can be no true faith. Thus, people who are ignorant of the true Gospel of Christ will not have true faith.

Assensus simply means agreement. It speaks of our firm conviction that the content of faith is true. A person may know about the doctrines of the Christian faith, but he may not believe that they are true. Genuine faith says that the content (the notitia) revealed in Holy Scripture is true.

Fiducia takes one step further than assensus, from more than just agreement to personal trust. It is not enough to know and believe the content of the Christian faith because "the devils also believe, and tremble" [James 2:19]. True saving faith comes when a sinner knows and believes the scriptural claims of the Lord Jesus Christ, and personally appropriates Him for salvation. It is a yielding of oneself to Christ. Fiducia is seen in Thomas' confession after he had seen the resurrected Christ, he not only believed but proclaimed, "My Lord and my God" [John 20:28].

11 JUNE.part4: Whom God hath set forth to be a propitiation through faith in his blood, to declare his righteousness for the remission of sins that are past, through the forbearance of God.
11 JUNE.part5:
Romans 3:25 says that our propitiation is through faith in the blood of the Lord Jesus Christ. Scripture teaches that we are redeemed by the blood of our Lord. Paul states that in Christ, "we have redemption through his blood, the forgiveness of sins, according to the riches of his grace" [Ephesians 1:7; see also Acts 20:28]. We are also justified by the blood of Christ [see Romans 5:8-9]. The concept of substitutionary atonement runs through the doctrine of salvation. For a sinner to live, an innocent life must die. The writer of Hebrews states that "without shedding of blood is no remission" [Hebrews 9:22]. The wrath of God upon sin cannot be assuaged except by a qualified substitute who is willing to die in our stead. Animals cannot be our substitute because "it is not possible that the blood of bulls and of goats should take away sins" [Hebrews 10:4]. Neither are we "redeemed with corruptible things, as silver and gold" [1 Peter 1:18-19]. Redemption comes only by the precious blood of the Lord Jesus. He is the only willing and qualified substitute in our place.

He was set forth by God to "be a propitiation through faith in (Christ's) blood". What do we understand by propitiation through faith in His blood? Is the blood of the Lord Jesus Christ a reference to His life, to His suffering and death, or to both? John Calvin says, "By mentioning blood only, [Paul] did not mean to exclude other things connected with redemption, but, on the contrary, to include the whole under one word." The shed blood of our Lord Jesus is His life poured out, and only His poured-out life can atone for our sins.

We must be humble to accept that if we are to be saved at all, it must be - and only be - by faith in the sacrifice of Jesus Christ.
11 JUNE.part7: What can wash away our sins? Nothing but the blood of Jesus. - Robert Lowry

12 JUNE.part4: To declare, I say, at this time his righteousness: that he might be just, and the justifier of him which believeth in Jesus.
12 JUNE.part5:
One objection we often encounter when sharing the Gospel with unbelievers, especially those who subscribe to the Buddhistic philosophy of karma, is that our Christian God is unfair. "You mean an evil person like Hitler can go to heaven simply because he believes in Jesus Christ?" they will ask. The philosophy of cause and effect, that "whatsoever a man sow, so shall he reap" enshrined even in our Holy Scriptures, demands that a wicked person should be punished for his crimes and misdeeds.

In this section of Romans, Paul provides the answer. Yes, God indeed will be unfair and unjust if He arbitrarily pardons a wicked criminal without punishment. But He did not. He sent His only begotten Son to die on the cross for the criminal and for our sins. The Lord Jesus shed His blood to satisfy God's wrath. The death of Jesus demonstrates justice has been served. The word "righteousness" in today's verse refers to God's justice. The righteous God did not just shrug off our sins. "The wages of sin is death" [Romans 6:23]; and the Lord Jesus, who was innocent of all sin, shed His precious blood on the cross and paid the penalty we deserved.

To justify is to declare the accused righteous. God, the righteous Judge, can declare us righteous because He sent His Son to die for our sins. He is therefore also our justifier. But to receive this benefit, we must believe in and accept the gift, Jesus the Christ. We need to repent of our sins and receive Him as our Lord and Saviour.
12 JUNE.part7: In the doctrine of salvation by grace, man is nothing, Christ is all. - James Smith, Daily Remembrancer

13 JUNE.part4: Where is boasting then? It is excluded. By what law? of works? Nay: but by the law of faith.

He provides the answer - No! Man has nothing to boast of, not of observing the Law nor of doing good deeds? No, except in the principle of believing by faith [1 Corinthians 1:31].

Paul's teachings in this chapter is needful for many liberals of our day who are misled to think that all religions are good, teach people to be good and thus make them acceptable in God's sight. May the Lord use us as channels to point such people to the Word of Truth to see what God really thinks of our self-righteousness.

17 JUNE.part2: Is the Law Voided by Faith?
17 JUNE.part4: Do we then make void the law through faith? God forbid: yea, we establish the law.
17 JUNE.part5:
The apostle Paul asks, "Do we then make void the law through faith?" If we are justified apart from the Law, is the Law thus made void? He is asking, "Is the Law thus ineffective?" His answer - "God forbid: yea (yes), we establish the Law". The phrase 'God forbids' (in Greek, me genioto) means 'absolutely not' or 'may it never be'. Paul declares we establish the Law. 'Establish' (histemi) is 'to cause something or someone to stand'.

What is justification? According to the answer of Westminster shorter Catechism, Question 33, "Justification is an act of God's free grace, wherein He pardoneth all our sins, and accepteth us as righteous in his sight, only for the righteousness of Christ imputed to us, and received by faith alone." Justification (being declared right with God) is by faith in Christ alone, not by works. It is impossible to attain right standing with God by keeping the Law. The Law requires perfect obedience to every commandment, not only external behaviour, but also compliance on the heart level. We cannot be saved by keeping the Law. Neither is it the Law's purpose to save us. Rather, it is to show us our sins so that we will despair of being saved by our inability to keep the Law and look to the Lord Jesus Christ instead.

Justification by faith upholds the Law by showing that the punishment the Law demanded has been met by our Lord Jesus Christ [v. 25] shedding His blood as a propitiation of our sins. That means, when our Lord Jesus died on the cross for our sins, the wrath of God for our rebellion against Him fell on His Son instead. God imputed the righteousness of Christ to us. Thus today's verse teaches us that the Law is vital and operative, but not as a means of salvation.
17 JUNE.part7: The doctrine of justification is by grace through faith, and our Lord Jesus upholds the Law of God rather than subverts it.

Abraham was the first patriarch and Jews believed that his inherent righteousness moved God to make him the father of His chosen people. In other words, Abraham's good works earned God's favour and salvation. However, Abraham was not sinless but despite that, God promised his seed would be as numerous as the stars. God established a covenant with Abraham and placed the obligation to fulfil its promises on Himself [Genesis 15:17]. This covenant would be an everlasting covenant between God and Abraham and all his seed. [Genesis 17:7-8]. He would be their God and Canaan would be their everlasting possession.

This covenant was initiated by God and Abraham responded in simple faith, believing God would fulfil everything He promised. God did not save Abraham on the basis of his goodness but on the righteousness of our Lord Jesus, whom God foreknew would die to save sinners one day [Genesis 15:6]. Every person who is saved before or after the advent of our Lord Jesus shares the same faith Abraham had and is saved by the same gift of God's grace. While Abraham's physical offspring secured the Promised Land of Canaan, Abraham's spiritual seed will gain an everlasting heavenly home. Thank God for His matchless grace and mercy to mankind.

By calling Abraham "our father" [v. 1], Paul was not restricting the question to Jews only as the Book of Romans was addressed to the Christians in Rome. While the Jews regard Abraham as their physical forefather, Abraham was also the spiritual forefather of all Christians who place their faith in the Lord Jesus as their Saviour.

24 JUNE.part4: For what saith the scripture? Abraham believed God, and it was counted unto him for righteousness.
24 JUNE.part5:
What does it mean to be counted righteous? The word "counted" in Greek carries the idea of "imputed to" or "reckoned to". This tells us that Abraham's belief in God did not make him inherently righteous. Rather, the righteousness of another - the Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ - would be imputed to him. This is a wonderful thing indeed! All of Abraham's sinfulness and doubt in God would be washed and dealt satisfactorily with. When we believe in and accept Christ as our Lord and Saviour, we too are imputed with the righteousness of Christ. When God examines us, He will not but choose to ignore our sins and put onto our account the righteousness of Christ, which fully satisfies God's holiness, justice and love. This is something we must be eternally grateful for, because we could never have done it on our own. Man's inherent sin nature means that from conception, we were steeped in sin [Psalm 51:5]. It was impossible for us to live the perfectly sinless life that the Lord Jesus Christ did on our behalf.

Therefore, let us strive to show our love for Him by leading holy lives. When we fully appreciate what God has done for us, our desire to forsake sin grows not because we want to "earn" salvation, but because we want to show our love and gratitude to the God who saved us.

25 JUNE.part4: Now to him that worketh is the reward not reckoned of grace, but of debt.
25 JUNE.part5:
The discourse here is addressed directly to the Jew, to prove to him that the doctrine of justification is not something new. Paul proceeds to show, in today's verse, that Abraham was not justified by works, but by faith and free grace. Hence, there are no grounds to boast about attaining justification through good works by comparing between one who works to earn his salvation and one who does not but claims it by faith. Verse 4 first supposes that to the one who works (or so he thinks) with the intent of gaining justification through his actions, salvation would be owed him. This is the general principle pertaining to legal contracts, where one who fulfils the terms is entitled to fair compensation (that is, "debt" in today's verse) promised, which he can rightfully claim. Hence, if one has fulfilled the contract, payment to him is not a matter of favour, but what he has duly earned. He is deserving of remuneration.

Therefore, if someone was justified by his actions and works, he would have a claim on God's favour because it would be wrong not to compensate him for the works he has done. This supposition is thus contrary to the doctrine of grace (see Romans 11:6).

Of course, Paul is not affirming one's ability to attain justification through his merits but speaking hypothetically of one who can fulfill the condition of perfect obedience. The fact is no one can be saved through their own efforts because none can obey perfectly. The discourse continues in verse 5.
25 JUNE.part7: Grace, grace, God's grace, Grace that will pardon and cleanse within; Grace, grace, God's grace, Grace that is greater than all our sin! - Peter P. Bilhorn

26 JUNE.part4: But to him that worketh not, but believeth on him that justifieth the ungodly, his faith is counted for righteousness.
26 JUNE.part5:
Verse 4 presents the hypothetical scenario that if one can fulfil the condition of perfect obedience, then justification (or salvation) is not an act of God's grace, but something that the person deserves as payment. Paul continues here the contrasting scenario that instead of one's perfect adherence to the Law (by works), he seeks to be justified by believing - this is the idea of justification by all who believe in the Lord Jesus.

The expression "believeth on him that justifieth the ungodly" highlights an important point. The ungodly sinners (that is, all of us) are not being justified because we are righteous. We are corrupt and deserve no favour, but God unilaterally resolves to forgive the ungodly, and to treat us as His friends.

"...his faith is counted for righteousness." The sinners' faith in the Lord Jesus renders him to be justified by God even though he has been, and still is, and will always be, personally undeserving of this merit. This act of justification is based on the premise that our Lord Jesus died in our place to atone for our sins. The 'benefits' of the Lord Jesus Christ's atoning death is therefore imputed to believers in Christ. This act of our Lord renders it possible for God to regard all who base their faith in Christ, as righteous and treat them as though they had themselves obeyed the Law in His sight.

Like Abraham, by believing in God, it will be counted to us for righteousness [v. 3].

27 JUNE.part4: Even as David also describeth the blessedness of the man, unto whom God imputeth righteousness without works.
27 JUNE.part5:
The word "impute" (Gr. logizomai) holds great theological meaning in the narrative of God's saving grace and act of salvation. It has the meaning of setting something to one's account, or to reckon something to an individual.

The act of counting (or crediting) unto Abraham righteousness [Genesis 15:6; Romans 4:3] is an ideal example of imputation where God regarded him as righteous. It reckons or attributes to an individual something which he did not have in himself. Like Abraham, David is also cited as another recipient of this free and unmerited grace, where this righteousness of the Lord Jesus Christ is imputed to him (verse 6-8). This righteousness is imputed so that while it is not the sinner's own, yet God counts it as his. Martin Luther puts it succinctly: simul justus ac peccator - justified and a sinner simultaneously.

The word imputation is also used as in reckoning man's sin to our Lord Jesus. This is where two truths of salvation converge - the burden of man's sin became Christ's burden, while God's righteousness became ours. Such is the great exchange.

"For he hath made him to be sin for us, who knew no sin; that we might be made the righteousness of God in him" [2 Corinthians 5:21]. Of course, there was the imputation of Adam's sinfulness to all mankind based on the narrative of the fall in the beginning [Genesis 3]. Adam's sin was imputed to his posterity because he represented the human race [1 Corinthians 15:21]. But the more important question is this - Do you have the righteousness of Christ imputed to you?
27 JUNE.part7: Father in heaven, I thank You for the great exchange You have executed in Your great salvation plan that through the sacrifice of our Lord Jesus, His righteousness is imputed to me for my salvation. Thank You in Jesus' Name, Amen.

28 JUNE.part4: Saying, Blessed are they whose iniquities are forgiven, and whose sins are covered.
28 JUNE.part5:
Paul quotes David in Psalm 32:1-2a. This psalm may have been written after David's repentance for his adultery with Bathsheba. Have you committed sins you regret, sins that have resulted in sleepless nights, sins that have scarred your loved ones? Have you come before the Lord in genuine repentance yet the pain lingers?

David has something to tell you today. Hearken to his testimony here and see how blessed the Christian is. He says in Psalm 32:1, "Blessed is he whose transgression is forgiven, whose sin is covered." The word "blessed" means "happy". The Christian who realises he is forgiven is a happy Christian.

Instead of wallowing in self-pity and suffering in sorrow, David calls us to experience the joy in God's forgiving grace. Our focus now ought to be on God's forgiveness and not on our past sin. God's forgiveness is a well-established biblical fact and not a 'feeling' we must attain to feel better. Surely, we have to first repent and make peace with both God and man. Thereafter, we are not to dwell on those thoughts of grief, despair and sorrow, but embrace the fact that the Lord Jesus Christ has died on the cross for a specific reason (our sins) by reading His Word and engaging in intimate prayer.

Dear Christian, realise the rich grace of the Lord Jesus Christ who perished for you. He died so you may live for Him and not linger in self-pity, doubt and sorrow. This day, be encouraged that God forgives all who come before Him in genuine repentance, regardless of what sins your past may be filled with.
28 JUNE.part7: Christ's blood covers all our sins, no matter how grievous you think they are.

29 JUNE.part4: Saying, Blessed are they whose iniquities are forgiven, and whose sins are covered.
29 JUNE.part5:
Often, we encounter God's blessings in the form of receiving something - strength, perseverance, wisdom, provision. It almost seems abnormal to get a blessing from God where we do not receive.

Today we see Paul's exposition of Psalm 32:2a where God's forgiveness of sins is likened to God not reckoning judgement to people for what they deserve. Imagine yourself in a courtroom where instead of being judged and condemned for your sinful acts, you are acquitted and pronounced 'not guilty'. The reason you are acquitted has nothing to do with anything you have done or any qualities you embody. It is merely because the Judge declares so.

This is what Paul is stating here when he says, "Blessed are they whose iniquities are forgiven." The forgiving of iniquities is entirely God's prerogative and has nothing to do with us. There is nothing good in us that warrants forgiveness. By not giving us the punishment we truly deserve for our sins, Paul says that this is a blessing that we ought to be happy and thankful for.

With this in mind, do we find ourselves thinking we deserve a reward for doing something good for God? Take a look at our sins and realise that even the "smallest sin" demands judgement. A white lie? Prideful thought? Envy at someone who has something you do not have? In our holy God's eyes, sin whether big or small, calls for the same payment - eternal damnation.

We are blessed when God does not give us what we truly deserve. We all deserve death, but the debt of our sin has been paid in full.
29 JUNE.part7: Realise how many sins we have been forgiven.

30 JUNE.part4: Saying, Blessed are they whose iniquities are forgiven, and whose sins are covered.
30 JUNE.part5:
As Christians, we usually think that we need to repent of and change our old ways after we commit sin. In the attempt to do so, we apply a set of rules and boundaries to abide by in order to change. We approach other believers to help keep us accountable to our rules and we pray often for strength from God to keep us from breaking these rules.

We may do this because it seems easier for us to follow a set of 'rules' adopted from biblical principles than to have a heart fully surrendered and devoted to God. We may also do this because we do not fully understand the message of the Gospel.

The focus today is on our sins being covered. This means that when the Lord Jesus Christ died on the cross, all sin (past, present and future) is covered by His blood. As a result of His covering and we accepting this as ours, we become new beings in Christ, indwelt by the Holy Spirit and filled with new delights and desires. With God's Spirit working and active in us comes the yearning to change our sinful behaviours and emotions into those pleasing to Him. Change begins when we realise that the Lord Jesus Christ has covered our sins.

When we sin, we have to acknowledge that we are incapable of changing our old sin nature by ourselves. Only God can change us, and God has changed us by covering us with His Son's righteousness, so we may be righteous, and live righteously and victoriously through Him.
30 JUNE.part7: What have I done to change my sinful lifestyle? Was I relying on my own strength to change?
